At-a-Glance: Consistent, quantitative mite sampling beats guesswork. Alcohol washes are the reference standard; sugar rolls and CO₂ give alternatives with different trade-offs.
Why it Matters: Threshold-based actions prevent over- or under-treating. Comparable results across yards let you evaluate treatment efficacy and resistance risk.
Step-by-Step: Sample ~300 bees from the brood nest. Alcohol wash: submerge and agitate; count mites vs bees. Sugar roll: dust, roll, and shake out; return live bees. CO₂: anesthetise briefly and separate mites. Record % infestation and repeat at set calendar points.
Seasonality & Climate: Sample in spring build-up, post-spring flow, post-harvest, and pre-winter. In continuous-brood climates, add mid-season checks.
Common Pitfalls: Sampling foragers instead of nurse bees, too few bees, inconsistent shaking times, and comparing different methods without conversion.
Tools & Materials: Marked sampling jar/cup, alcohol or powdered sugar/CO₂ kit, scoop for counts, notebook or digital logs.
